title: Advertisers are starting to pull the plug on The Kyle and Jackie O Show over the Virgin Mary scandal
text:
Kyle and Jackie O are still bearing the brunt over the Virgin Mary scandal as a prominent advertiser pulls the plug on the show.

An Australian not-for-profit business, Speckle, has stopped advertising with the KIIS FM radio show following the 48-year-old's controversial Virgin Mary joke.

'We are strong advocates for the respect and empowerment of women and their families, and do not condone any comments that are detrimental to this,' a spokesperson for Speckle told Confidential.

The spokesperson said Kyle's comments were 'inconsistent' with the company's values and the people they work with.

An Australian not-for-profit business, Speckle, has stopped advertising with the KIIS FM radio show following the 48-year-old's (pictured) controversial Virgin Mary joke

Protesters gathered outside the KIIS FM studio calling for Kyle to be sacked following his comments

Despite issuing an eight-minute apology to Christians and Muslims, and other offended viewers, the show faces an exodus from other advertisers.

A2 Milk said they are reviewing their deal with the show but have welcomed the apology.

Other advertisers such as Booking.com and Budget Direct are also considering their options in light of the vilifying comments.

Church & Dwight was the first to pull their ads from the popular radio show.

An ARN spokesperson confirmed to the publication that they are working with their advertisers to address any issues.

'If ever there are questions raised by our advertisers, we address them immediately,' the spokesperson said.

'The recent issue was managed in the best possible way, in that, when this content ran we immediately recognised that it wasn't appropriate for distribution and it was removed immediately.'

An ARN spokesperson confirmed to the publication that they are working with their advertisers to address any issues (Pictured Kyle and Jackie O)

Kyle sparked outrage when he claimed Mary was not actually a virgin, and one public relations expert believes the comments could cost him sponsorship

Last month, Kyle sparked outrage when he claimed Mary was not actually a virgin.

'I thought Mary was his (Jesus Christ's) girlfriend but apparently it was the mother,' he said.

'And the mother lied obviously and told everyone, 'Nah I got pregnant by a magical ghost'. Bullsh*t.

'Someone chock-a-blocked her behind the camel shed … You might believe everything that's written down 2000 years ago to be absolutely accurate and good on you, you're dumb. Dumb as dog sh*t.'

His remarks led to protesters of multiple faiths gathering outside the KIIS Sydney studios calling for Kyle to be sacked.

'The ACMA has received over 150 complaints regarding the comments made by Mr Sandilands about the Virgin Mary,' a spokesperson told Daily Mail Australia

The Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) confirmed it had received dozens of complaints.

'The ACMA has received over 150 complaints regarding the comments made by Mr Sandilands about the Virgin Mary,' a spokesperson told Daily Mail Australia.

'Under the co-regulatory system, the ACMA will refer complainants to the broadcaster in the first instance.

'If the complainant does not receive a response from the broadcaster within 60 days, or is not satisfied with the response, they may refer their complaint to the ACMA.'

Daily Mail Australia has contacted Speckle, Booking.com, A2 Milk, Budget Direct and Church & Dwight for comment.

authors: Sahar Mourad For Daily Mail Australia
